children.content: Check the state of the pupil
The pupil is unreactive and fixed in a mid-dilated position.

children.node: Pupil appears normal but APD present
children.content: The pupil looks normal, but further evaluation shows a relative afferent pupillary defect (APD).
Check for symptoms of giant cell arteritis
Symptoms of giant cell arteritis include jaw claudication, scalp tenderness, headache, malaise, anorexia, and proximal joint or muscle aches.
Symptoms of retinal detachment include photopsias, floaters, and a curtain or shadow moving in the field of vision.
On ophthalmoscopy, the infarcted retina appears whitish and opacified, with a cherry-red spot in the center of the macula.
Ophthalmoscopic examination in central retinal vein occlusion reveals diffuse retinal hemorrhages, dilated retinal veins, and often cotton-wool spots.
